key_points: Following the Nov. 30 Oxford High School shooting, dozens of students, including children as young as 9, face charges for alleged threats of violence.
Incidents are part of a nationwide trend of "copycat" threats against schools.
In metro Detroit, at least two dozen students have been taken into custody or charged in recent days.
Authorities are issuing stern warnings about the serious consequences of making threats, even in jest.
In Waterford, four students, including two 9-year-olds, were detained for making threats and creating concerning lists.
Two middle school students in Waterford have been charged with making a false threat of terrorism, potentially facing 20 years in prison.
Police Chief Scott Underwood emphasized the importance of parents discussing the severity of making threats with their children.
Wayne County Prosecutor Kym Worthy reported charging 18 youths in recent days for related crimes and stressed the need for community effort to address the issue.
Worthy's office has been working to educate parents and students on the risks since 2018, and emphasized the need to confront access to guns and their portrayal.
The Oakland County Sheriff’s Office is investigating a note found in a high school, though it appears not to constitute a credible threat.
spokespersons: Scott Underwood (Police Chief, Waterford Police Department)
